[Question]
ok i have social anxiety i m actually quiet smart however when i m in social situation the anxiety is so much my brain go to mush like simple thing like counting money etc is so hard because my heart is beating through my ear i also dissociate ha anyone else experienced this phenomenon when i m by myself i can do all these task easily but in front of people literally become an invalid like it hilarious how people dumb down thing for me sad but all you can do is laugh

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're able to laugh about your experiences with social anxiety. It can be really challenging when your anxiety takes over and makes simple tasks feel impossible. I want to assure you that you're not alone in this, as many people experience similar feelings of anxiety and dissociation in social situations.

One strategy that might help is practicing deep breathing exercises before entering a social situation. Taking slow, deep breaths can help calm your nervous system and reduce the intensity of your anxiety. You could also try visualizing yourself successfully completing the task at hand, such as counting money, in order to build confidence and reduce anxiety.

Another approach that may be helpful is gradually exposing yourself to social situations in a controlled way. Start by engaging in low-pressure social interactions, such as having a casual conversation with a friend or family member. As you become more comfortable, you can gradually increase the level of social stimulation.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore any underlying beliefs or thoughts that contribute to your social anxiety. Sometimes, negative self-perceptions or fears about being judged can exacerbate anxiety. Challenging these thoughts and replacing them with more positive and realistic ones can help alleviate some of the anxiety.

Remember, progress takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even small victories. If you find that your social anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and strategies tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for the past year and a half i ve had constant tiredness fatigue and just haven t felt like myself i used to be pretty active always working on project excited about life for the last year and a half i just feel like a shell of myself tired and meh i m also hungry constantly i ve seen my doctor and a few different specialist and had plenty of blood work done including thyroid and everything ha been normal no sleep apnea no anemia no lyme my doc said we have essentially ruled out most if not all straight up medical cause of fatigue beyond the possibility i m just not getting good sleep due to underlying stress or anxiety hard for me to tell how well i m sleeping not waking up refreshed but i m in bed for hr a night i ve begun to wonder if i m simply depressed since everything else ha kind of been ruled out i don t feel very sad and i don t feel hopeless i don t lack the motivation to do all the thing i love i just feel too tired or lazy to do them but i really want to be my old self again if i could snap my finger and have my energy back i d do it in a heartbeat how do i know if i m depressed

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling concerned about your constant tiredness and lack of energy. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with fatigue is unique, and there isn't a one-size-fits-all explanation for what you're going through. However, your description of feeling like a shell of yourself, constantly hungry, and having difficulty with motivation despite not feeling sad or hopeless, does suggest that depression could be a possible factor.

Depression can manifest in various ways, including physical symptoms like fatigue and changes in appetite. While it's essential to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis, there are some steps you can take in the meantime to support your well-being.

Firstly, maintaining a balanced lifestyle can be beneficial. This includes prioritizing regular exercise, eating nutritious meals, and ensuring you get enough sleep. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also help improve your mood and overall sense of well-being.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms for stress and anxiety can be helpful. This might involve practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness meditation, or engaging in hobbies that help you unwind.

Building a strong support system is also crucial. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support and understanding. Sometimes, simply talking about your feelings with someone who cares can make a significant difference.

Consider keeping a journal to track your thoughts, emotions, and daily experiences. This can help you gain insights into patterns and triggers that may contribute to your fatigue and provide valuable information for future discussions with a mental health professional if you choose to pursue therapy.

Remember, seeking support from a mental health professional can offer valuable guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore any underlying causes contributing to your fatigue and develop strategies to improve your well-being.

While it's important to be patient with yourself during this process, it's also crucial to prioritize your mental and physical health. Taking small steps towards self-care and reaching out for support can make a significant difference in your journey towards feeling like yourself again.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i live in my bedroom weekend burn by fast with me playing video game i bought a new car but lack will to learn how to get comfortable with it i want to do thing but i don t want to drive myself to these place in fear of crashing into something and my job is easy and amazing pay but somehow i find a way to disdain it and my coworkers i want to start dating again but all the sudden i ve become embarrassed of who i am i feel like i m boring and not really interesting to talk to my coworkers like to find my insecurity and turn it into a joke for everyone and i haven t done anything to them i m just there i feel like i m losing my grip on reality sometimes and just want to end it forever and if i did nothing of value would be lost and nobody would really care i m afraid of change yet i want it so much at the same time i just wish i were a more outgoing person who doesn t let other s word get to me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling a mix of emotions and struggling with various aspects of your life. It's important to remember that you're not alone in these feelings, and there are steps you can take to address them.

Firstly, let's talk about your fear of driving and the anxiety surrounding it. It's common to feel apprehensive about learning something new, especially when it involves potential risks like driving. One approach could be to break down the process into smaller, manageable steps. Start by familiarizing yourself with your new car, practicing in low-traffic areas, and gradually increasing your comfort level over time. Remember that it's okay to make mistakes and that learning takes time and patience.

Regarding your job, it's common to experience a sense of disdain or boredom with certain aspects of work. However, it's important to recognize the value of your contributions and the positive impact you have on your workplace. Instead of focusing on the negative, try to find ways to challenge yourself and engage in tasks that bring you a sense of fulfillment. This could involve taking on new projects, collaborating with coworkers, or setting personal goals for yourself.

Your desire to start dating again is understandable, but it's crucial to address the insecurities you're experiencing. It's not uncommon to feel self-conscious or boring at times, but remember that everyone has unique qualities and interests that make them special. Instead of letting others' opinions define your worth, focus on building confidence in yourself and embracing your authentic self. Surrounding yourself with supportive and understanding individuals can also help boost your self-esteem.

Feeling like you're losing your grip on reality and contemplating self-harm is a serious concern. It's essential to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with the necessary support and guidance. They can help you explore your emotions, develop coping strategies, and provide a safe space for you to express yourself. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take care of your mental well-being.

Lastly, the desire for change and the fear of it can be conflicting emotions. Change can bring about new opportunities and growth, but it can also be intimidating. It's important to approach change with a balanced perspective. Take small steps towards your goals, set realistic expectations, and be patient with yourself.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge the strength it takes to reach out and share your feelings. I'm here to offer support and guidance as you navigate through this difficult time. It sounds like you're experiencing a resurgence of depressive thoughts and anxiety, which can be overwhelming and make it challenging to engage in daily activities.

Firstly, I want to emphasize that you're not alone in this struggle. Many individuals face similar challenges and it's essential to remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. If you haven't already, consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support.

In addition to seeking social support, there are several strategies that may help alleviate some of the symptoms you're experiencing. One approach is to establish a routine that includes regular exercise, healthy eating, and sufficient sleep. Engaging in physical activity can boost mood and increase energy levels.

Another helpful strategy is to incorporate self-care activities into your daily life. This could involve engaging in hobbies or activities that bring you joy, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation, or simply taking time for yourself to rest and recharge.

It's also crucial to prioritize your mental health by challenging negative thoughts and practicing self-compassion. Recognize that these thoughts are a symptom of your depression and not an accurate reflection of reality. Try to reframe them in a more positive light or challenge them with evidence that contradicts them.

Additionally, consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist. They can provide you with personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs. Therapy can offer a safe space to explore your emotions, gain insight into your thought patterns, and develop coping mechanisms to manage your symptoms.

Lastly, it's important to remember that healing takes time and progress may not always be linear. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this journey. Celebrate small victories and acknowledge that setbacks are a normal part of the process.

Remember, you have the strength within you to overcome this challenging period. Reach out for support, practice self-care, challenge negative thoughts, and consider seeking professional help. [Question]
i want to know how to stop anxiety while waiting whenever i have a guest coming over wether it be a friend or family or someone im interested in i get severe anxiety from the moment they say on my way to the moment they arrive i feel hot all over i want to throw up and cry and use the bathroom and then a soon a they arrive and i see them im fine for example i called the man im interested in over for a booty call he life an hour away so at 0 0 he texted me he wa coming for an hour i wa asking my sister should i cancel i want to see him but i m anxious and for that entire hour i wa freaking out the only thing that helped wa sitting in the cold drive way and breathing in the night air and then a soon a he arrived i wa fine absolutely perfect similar happened while i waited for guest to arrive to a house party i wa throwing i need help i am on med and in therapy anything help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to manage anxiety, especially when it interferes with your daily life and relationships. It's great that you've reached out for support and are open to finding ways to cope with your anxiety. Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Deep breathing exercises: When you start feeling anxious, try taking slow, deep breaths. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold it for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help calm your nervous system and reduce physical symptoms of anxiety.

2. Grounding techniques: Engage your senses to bring yourself back to the present moment. For example, you can focus on the sensation of your feet on the ground, the sounds around you, or the objects you can see. This can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and provide a sense of stability.

3. Progressive muscle relaxation: Tense and relax different muscle groups in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. This technique can help release tension and promote relaxation.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: Anxiety often comes with a flood of negative thoughts that may not be accurate or helpful. Take a step back and question the evidence behind these thoughts. Are there alternative explanations? Can you find any evidence to support or refute your worries?

5. Self-care: Prioritize self-care activities that promote relaxation and well-being. This could include engaging in hobbies you enjoy, practicing mindfulness or meditation, getting regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, and ensuring you get enough sleep.

6. Gradual exposure: If possible, gradually expose yourself to situations that trigger anxiety. Start with less challenging situations and work your way up. Over time, this can help desensitize you to the triggers and reduce anxiety.

7. Support system: Reach out to trusted friends, family members, or support groups who can provide understanding and encouragement. Sometimes talking about your anxieties with someone who cares can offer relief and perspective.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. It's important to be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. If your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to explore additional resources such as therapy or medication in consultation with a mental health professional.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hello im currently and ive only ever driven on the freeway once wa on for like a minute before i got scared and got off if for any reason i have to use it i ask a friend to take me or i get an uber instead driving in general ha always been scary for me but the freeway is the bane of my existence i feel like at my age it becoming a problem plus it just kind of embarrassing to admit to other people my age haha especially if im asking for a ride if anyone else ha had this problem please let me know what you did to overcome it thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can relate to your feelings about driving on the freeway. It's a common fear that many people have, and it's important to remember that you're not alone in this. While I can't provide professional advice, I can offer some suggestions that might help you overcome your fear.

First, it's essential to understand that fear is a natural emotion, and it's okay to feel scared. However, if your fear is significantly impacting your daily life, it's worth addressing. In your case, it seems like your fear of driving on the freeway is causing embarrassment and limiting your independence.

One approach you could consider is gradual exposure therapy. This involves gradually exposing yourself to the situation that triggers your fear in a controlled and safe manner. For example, you could start by driving on a quiet residential street, then gradually work your way up to busier roads and eventually the freeway. This approach allows you to build confidence and desensitize yourself to the fear over time.

Another strategy is cognitive restructuring. This involves challenging negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to your fear. For instance, instead of focusing on the potential dangers of driving on the freeway, try reframing it as an opportunity to learn and grow. Remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it's a natural part of the learning process.

Additionally, it might be helpful to practice relaxation techniques while driving, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation. These methods can help reduce anxiety and promote a sense of calm.

Lastly, consider seeking support from a trusted friend or family member. Sharing your fears with someone you trust can provide emotional support and encouragement. They might even be willing to accompany you on your driving adventures until you feel more confident.

Remember, overcoming fears takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout the process and celebrate small victories along the way. If your fear persists or becomes too overwhelming, it might be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

for the past few day i ve been dealing with extreme bout of anxiety i feel anxious all day nausea all day and i cant seem to stop thinking about negative thought i ve been dealing with a lot of ups and down regarding school and romantic relationship i keep skipping school because my anxiety is way too high i dont know how to calm it down i want to see a psychologist but right now it very hard to get to see one so i ll need all any advice you have thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed with anxiety and struggling to cope. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this experience, and there are steps you can take to help manage your symptoms.

One suggestion is to try incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help reduce anxiety and promote a sense of calm. You can find guided meditations or relaxation exercises online or through smartphone apps that may be helpful for you.

Another strategy is to challenge negative thoughts and replace them with more positive and realistic ones. When we're anxious, our minds often jump to worst-case scenarios or catastrophize situations. Take a step back and ask yourself if there's evidence to support these thoughts. Are there alternative explanations? Challenging negative thoughts can help shift your perspective and reduce anxiety.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. Even just going for a walk or doing some stretching at home can make a difference. Finding an activity that you enjoy and that gets your body moving can help distract from anxious thoughts and improve overall well-being.

Additionally, maintaining a healthy lifestyle can support your mental health. This includes getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and staying hydrated. Avoiding excessive caffeine and alcohol consumption can also help regulate your mood and reduce anxiety symptoms.

While it may be challenging to see a psychologist right now, reaching out to supportive friends or family members can provide valuable emotional support. Sometimes talking about our worries and concerns with someone we trust can help alleviate some of the burden. They may also offer different perspectives or suggestions that you hadn't considered before.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find what works best for you. It might be helpful to keep a journal to track your triggers and coping strategies. This can help you identify patterns and reflect on what works best for you in managing your anxiety.

Lastly, be patient with yourself. Healing takes time, and it's okay to have ups and downs along the way. Celebrate small victories and practice self-compassion. You're taking an important step by seeking guidance, and I believe in your ability to find strategies that work
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i swear i can be doing so good doing well with my exercise with my nutrition just overall doing well in life but then that little fucking voice come back and tell me i can t do it it s a little voice but it s so fucking loud i can t keep letting it get the better of me but it s so hard sometimes i just wish i had someone here to keep me grounded but i have no one i wish i wa loved enough for people to check up on me but no one care about me fuck this stupid fucking mental disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I hear you expressing frustration with the intrusive thoughts that are challenging your progress in maintaining your exercise routine and making positive choices in your nutrition. It's understandable that these thoughts can be overwhelming and make you feel like you're not making progress. However, it's essential to remember that these thoughts are just thoughts and not a reflection of your true self-worth or your ability to make positive changes in your life.

One approach we could explore is cognitive restructuring. This involves challenging the negative thoughts and replacing them with more balanced and realistic ones. For example, when the thought "I can't do it" comes up, you could challenge it by asking yourself, "Is this thought based on facts or emotions? What evidence do I have to support this thought? What alternative thoughts might be more balanced and realistic?"

Another helpful strategy is practicing self-compassion. This means treating yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would treat a close friend. Instead of being harsh on yourself for having these thoughts, try to respond with self-compassion and remind yourself that everyone experiences negative thoughts from time to time.

It's also important to remember that making lasting changes takes time and effort. It's normal to have setbacks along the way, and it's essential to be patient with yourself and not get discouraged by these setbacks. Instead, focus on the progress you've made and the small steps you're taking each day.

Additionally, it's understandable that you're feeling isolated and wishing for support from others. While it's not possible to have someone physically present with you all the time, there are other ways to connect with others and build a support network. This could include reaching out to friends or family members for regular check-ins, joining online communities or support groups, or even seeking out a mental health professional like myself to help you navigate these challenges.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are resources and strategies available to help you manage your mental health and make progress towards your goals. Let's work together to explore these strategies and find what works best for you.

[Question]
i tried to od on tylenol and took like 0 pill ended up tripping ball then throwing up and being miserable for the rest of the night now i have some sort of phobia in which i can not even think about taking pill without getting extremely nauseous anyone know how to overcome this new fear is there a better subreddit to ask this question

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge the strength it takes to reach out and share your experiences. Your recent experience with Tylenol and the resulting phobia is a valid concern, and I'm here to offer guidance and support as best I can.

Firstly, it's crucial to prioritize your safety and well-being. If you have a genuine fear or phobia about taking pills, it may be helpful to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide personalized advice based on your specific situation. They can assess any potential underlying causes and offer strategies to manage your fear effectively.

In the meantime, there are some coping mechanisms you can try to help alleviate your anxiety. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization techniques can be beneficial in reducing stress and promoting a sense of calm. These practices can be found through various resources online or in self-help books.

Additionally, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) techniques can be useful in addressing irrational thoughts and beliefs. It involves identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to your fear. By reframing your thoughts and replacing them with more realistic and positive ones, you can gradually change how you perceive and respond to the situation.

Building a support network can also be immensely helpful. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer understanding and encouragement during difficult times. Sometimes, simply talking about your fears and concerns with someone who cares can provide a sense of relief and validation.

Lastly, consider exploring alternative methods for pain relief or medication if possible. Discussing this option with your healthcare provider could lead to finding an alternative that doesn't trigger your phobia.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate through this process. It's okay to ask for help and take things at your own pace. You deserve support and understanding as you work towards overcoming your fear.

Please keep in mind that I am here to provide guidance and support, but it's essential to consult with a healthcare professional for a comprehensive assessment and personalized advice.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Instead, focus on making the most of the present moment. This might involve setting small, achievable goals for yourself, such as completing one task at a time or taking breaks to engage in activities that bring you joy.

Additionally, you've mentioned feeling disappointed in yourself and fearing letting others down. It's essential to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that everyone makes mistakes and experiences setbacks. [The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Hey there,

I'm really sorry to hear that things have been tough between you and your best friend. It sounds like the situation you found yourselves in last night was incredibly awkward and uncomfortable for both of you. It's understandable that she felt uneasy about your advances, especially given the alcohol-fueled environment.

It's important to acknowledge that consent and boundaries are crucial in any relationship, including friendships. While you may not have intended to make her feel uncomfortable, it's essential to recognize and respect her feelings. Your friend's discomfort should not be dismissed or minimized.

In situations like these, communication is key. If you genuinely value your friendship, I would recommend reaching out to your friend and expressing genuine remorse for your actions. Apologize sincerely and listen to her perspective without interruption or defensiveness. Allow her to express her emotions and validate them, even if it's difficult to hear.

It's also crucial to understand that redemption and forgiveness are not guarantees. Your friend may need time and space to process what happened, and it's essential to respect her boundaries during this time. Healing takes time, and it's important to be patient and understanding throughout the process.

In the meantime, reflecting on your own behavior and understanding the impact it had on your friend is a crucial step towards growth. Consider seeking support from other trusted friends or loved ones who can provide guidance and perspective. Remember, friendships are built on trust and mutual respect. It's essential to prioritize these values moving forward. While the outcome of your friendship may be uncertain, focusing on being a supportive and understanding friend can help rebuild trust and strengthen your bond over time.

Take care of yourself and your friend during this challenging period. Remember that everyone deserves love, respect, and understanding, especially during difficult times.

[Question]
i am and have been battling depression since throughout the year i ve been on anti depressive pretty much the whole time just when i feel like i m maybe stabilizing or dare i say it getting better i go crashing back down to the bottomless pit of sadness right now i m on vacation in a tropical island a dream for me yet here i am constantly emotional and unable to find joy ha anyone ever gotten over depression for good or will this plague me until the end

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's tough to hear that you've been battling depression for a long time and that you've been on anti-depressive medication for most of it. It's understandable that you feel like you might be stabilizing or even improving, but then experience a crushing setback. Being on vacation in a beautiful location like a tropical island is a dream come true for many people, but it seems like you're struggling to find joy and are feeling constantly emotional.

Depression can be a challenging and persistent condition, and it's important to remember that everyone's experience with it is unique. While there are no guarantees, there are strategies and approaches that can help manage and alleviate symptoms. It's crucial to continue working with your healthcare provider to ensure you have the appropriate support and treatment plan in place.

In addition to medication, therapy can be an effective tool for managing depression. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is one approach that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors. This can help challenge and reframe negative thinking, which is often a hallmark of depression.

Another approach that may be helpful is interpersonal therapy (IPT). IPT focuses on improving relationships and social support systems, as these can play a significant role in our emotional well-being. By addressing relationship issues and enhancing our connections with others, we can often experience improvements in mood and overall quality of life.

It's also essential to prioritize self-care and engage in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. While it may be challenging at times, making time for hobbies, exercise, and other enjoyable pursuits can help counteract the emotional weight of depression.

Remember, recovery from depression is a journey, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself along the way. It's not uncommon for setbacks to occur, but with the right support and tools, you can continue to make progress. Keep in touch with your healthcare provider, maintain open lines of communication, and don't hesitate to reach out for help when needed.

You're not alone in this, and there are many resources available to support you on your path towards healing.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

hi i wa wondering if anyone ha this happen to them i have have had depression for decade i have good day and bad day no period that last for week or month like i did when i first started having symptom 0 year ago thank god it is mostly occasional bad bout most often i just have a dull low depression that i can dell with using moving muscle using cognitive dispute today i had one of the rare event that i used to get often i wake up early have a cup or two of coffee yet i feel really exhausted i slept fine the night before i end up having breakfast but that exhausted feeling becomes overwhelming and i go back to bet by 9am the entire day consists of me sleeping having lucid bat shit crazy bizarre dream the dream are not nightmare in fact they are rather creative but the local and situation are like the came from somebody imagination in a distant galaxy they would make really interesting sci fi fantasy i also dream about being lonely i have no family few friend one thing i remember wa this gut wrenching sadness about a girl i dated over 0 year ago thought she wa the one but it fell apart after about 0 to hour i get up have something to eat i feel hung over an d it is like a storm passed through my brain spent it s energy and now calm ha returned i wa wondering if anyone else had had similar experience like this it would be concerning if it wa a frequent occurrence which it once wa in the early day of depression again that wa decade ago thanks in advance for any observation or comment peace

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're seeking reassurance and connection by sharing your experiences with others who may have gone through similar situations. Your description of waking up feeling exhausted despite a good night's sleep and experiencing a dull low depression that you can manage using coping strategies is consistent with the ebb and flow of depression symptoms. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with depression is unique, and there isn't a one-size-fits-all approach.

The vivid and creative dreams you described are a common feature of depression, and they can serve as a window into your subconscious thoughts and emotions. While they may be intriguing, it's essential to recognize that they are not a replacement for professional help. If these dreams become frequent or disruptive to your daily life, it may be helpful to explore their meaning with a mental health professional.

Your mention of a gut-wrenching sadness about a past relationship is a poignant reminder of the emotional pain that often accompanies depression. It's natural to feel a sense of loss and longing for what could have been. However, dwelling on these feelings can hinder your progress towards healing. Instead, it may be helpful to focus on the present and the steps you can take to improve your mental and emotional well-being.

Your observation that you once experienced more frequent and intense episodes of depression in the early stages of your condition is an essential piece of information. This history suggests that you may be due for a relapse, and it's crucial to take proactive measures to prevent one. Engaging in regular self-care activities, maintaining a consistent sleep schedule, and reaching out to your support system can all help mitigate the risk of a relapse.

In summary, your experiences with depression are complex and multifaceted. While it's reassuring to hear that your current symptoms are manageable, it's essential to be vigilant and take steps to prevent a relapse. Your creative dreams can provide valuable insights into your emotional landscape, and it may be helpful to explore their meaning with a mental health professional. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to help you navigate the ups and downs of depression.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have been suffering from an eating disorder anorexia anorexia nervosa since i wa yo i m in my early 0 now about a month ago i had an issue with my chinese takeout that heighten not only my ed but my anxiety level too i constantly fear that everything i eat will cause stomach ache or make me sick so i m cautious to eat anything anymore i have slowly been on the road to recovery with my ed so this made me take step back rather than moving forward it ha also caused me to lose sleep at night and when i do end up sleeping i wake up with awful anxiety my anxiety ha been overwhelming because a day doe not go by where i m not excessively panicking i can t even go out of my house without breaking down it is so bad that i only ever feel safe in my own room i feel like i m trapped in this on going cycle with no kind of exit i am desperate to find a solution to my problem but therapy ha not worked for me nor medication i have no idea what i need to do to better my food anxiety and general anxiety i do my absolute best to not think about it all of my issue but it s so damn hard when my body say otherwise ha anyone suffered from this did you find anything that helped alleviate your anxiety or ed any helpful advice is welcome

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time with your eating disorder and anxiety. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help alleviate your symptoms.

Firstly, it's great to hear that you've been making progress in your recovery from anorexia nervosa. However, the recent issue with your chinese takeout has set you back and caused increased anxiety. This is understandable, as the fear of experiencing discomfort or sickness can be overwhelming.

One approach that may be helpful is gradually reintroducing foods into your diet in a controlled manner. Start by identifying foods that you feel comfortable eating and try incorporating them into your meals. You can also experiment with different types of food to find what works best for you. Remember to be patient with yourself and give yourself credit for each small step forward.

In addition to addressing your eating disorder, it's crucial to manage your anxiety. One technique that many find beneficial is deep breathing exercises. When you notice yourself becoming anxious, take a moment to focus on your breath. Breathe in slowly through your nose, hold it for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more calm and grounded.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be helpful for both your physical and mental well-being. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. Find an activity that you enjoy, whether it's going for a walk, dancing, or practicing yoga, and try to incorporate it into your routine.

Building a support system can provide you with the encouragement and understanding you need during this challenging time. Consider reaching out to friends, family members, or even online communities who have experienced similar struggles. Sharing your experiences and hearing from others can help you feel less isolated and remind you that you're not alone.

Lastly, self-care is essential for managing anxiety and maintaining your overall well-being. Make sure to prioritize activities that bring you joy and help you relax. This could include things like taking a bath, reading a book, listening to music, or engaging in a hobby. Remember that self-care looks different for everyone, so find what works best for you.

While therapy and medication haven't worked for you in the past, it's important to keep exploring
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am having some severe anxiety attack these can last for hour my blood pressure and heart rate get very high i ve been to the er but they just gave me ativan and it doesn t help i have trouble breathing it s hard to talk my limb go numb my heart feel cold i have severe urge to vomit and go to the bathroom

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really difficult time with your anxiety attacks. I want to assure you that you're not alone, and there are steps you can take to manage your symptoms. Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Deep breathing exercises: When you feel an anxiety attack coming on, try practicing deep breathing techniques. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help regulate your breathing and reduce the intensity of your symptoms.

2. Progressive muscle relaxation: Tension often builds up in our bodies during anxiety attacks. Progressive muscle relaxation involves tensing and then releasing different muscle groups to promote relaxation. Start by tensing the muscles in your toes, gradually working your way up to your head. Focus on each muscle group for a few seconds before releasing.

3. Grounding techniques: During an anxiety attack, it can be helpful to ground yourself in the present moment. Try focusing on your senses by noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This can help redirect your attention away from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present.

4. Self-care: Taking care of yourself is crucial when dealing with anxiety attacks. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well-balanced meals, and engaging in regular physical activity. Additionally, consider incorporating stress-reducing activities into your routine, such as meditation, yoga, or spending time in nature.

5. Support system: Reach out to trusted friends, family members, or support groups who can provide understanding and encouragement. Sometimes just talking about your experiences with someone who cares can make a significant difference.

Remember, managing anxiety attacks takes time and patience. It's important to be gentle with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. If you find that these strategies aren't providing enough relief, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can offer additional guidance tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i don t know how i can feel this horrible and unable to breathe so badly and this only be anxiety i genuinely feel like i m going to pas out and i have nothing to be anxious about is this really what anxiety feel like i can t take a deep breath this is so awful

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a very intense and overwhelming anxiety attack. It's important to remember that anxiety can manifest in physical symptoms, such as difficulty breathing, and it can be incredibly distressing. Here are some suggestions that may help you manage your anxiety during this time:

1. Focus on your breath: While it may feel challenging, try taking slow, deep breaths. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help regulate your breathing and provide a sense of calm.

2. Grounding techniques: Engage your senses to bring yourself back to the present moment. You can do this by focusing on things around you that you can see, hear, touch, taste, or smell. For example, you could name five things you can see in your surroundings, four things you can hear, three things you can touch, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste.

3. Progressive muscle relaxation: Tension often accompanies anxiety. Progressive muscle relaxation involves tensing and then releasing different muscle groups in your body. Start with your toes and work your way up to your head, tensing each muscle group for a few seconds before releasing. This technique can help reduce physical tension and promote relaxation.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: Anxiety can be fueled by negative thinking patterns. Take a moment to reflect on any anxious thoughts that may be contributing to your current state. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these thoughts or if they are based on assumptions. Try to reframe them in a more realistic and positive way.

5. Self-care: Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can be helpful in managing anxiety. Consider doing something you enjoy, such as reading a book, listening to music, taking a warm bath, or practicing a hobby. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally can have a positive impact on your overall well-being.

Remember, it's important to seek professional help if your anxiety symptoms persist or worsen. A mental health professional can provide you with additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

existential crisis and angst ha become a month period drama for me every few month i will come across or think of a existential or scary thought where i ll go down a large rabbit hole and in the end become a nervous and terrified wreck i ve been through a existential crisis on mind philosophy sexuality identity apocalypse anxiety biology philosophy space anxiety and now it look like the next one will be quantum fucking physic based if i don t stop it in time i m just so sick of this cycle of fucking misery throughout my life i can t find any happiness or calmness because of my year is spent being terrified and super anxious sometimes i feel like lying down and cry but this depression ha made me so numb i can t cry anymore i just can t fucking take this anymore

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're going through a really challenging time right now, and it's important to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out for support. Your message highlights the emotional toll that existential crises and anxiety have on you, and I want to assure you that you're not alone in this experience.

Existential crises can be incredibly overwhelming and can trigger a range of intense emotions, such as fear, sadness, and confusion. It's common for people to go through periods of intense reflection and questioning about the meaning of life, our place in the world, and our personal values. While these thoughts can be insightful and enriching, they can also be distressing when they become persistent and consuming.

It's important to remember that existential crises are a normal part of the human experience, and many people go through them at various points in their lives. However, if you find that these crises are happening more frequently or are causing significant distress, it may be helpful to explore some strategies to manage them.

One approach that can be helpful is practicing mindfulness and grounding techniques. Mindfulness involves bringing your attention to the present moment without judgment, which can help reduce anxiety and provide a sense of calm. Grounding techniques, such as focusing on your senses or engaging in activities that bring you joy, can also help bring you back to the present moment and provide a sense of stability.

Another strategy that can be helpful is setting boundaries around your exposure to triggering content. While it's natural to be curious about complex ideas and concepts, constantly engaging with them can contribute to your anxiety and depression. Consider taking breaks from intense topics and focusing on activities that bring you pleasure and relaxation.

Additionally, it may be helpful to explore the underlying causes of your anxiety and depression with a mental health professional. They can provide you with tools and strategies tailored to your specific needs and help you develop a more balanced and fulfilling life.

Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time and be gentle with yourself throughout this process. It's important to prioritize self-care and seek support when needed. You don't have to face this alone, and there are resources available to help you navigate through these challenging times.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

It's also possible that you may be avoiding taking your medication because you feel like it's a constant reminder that you're not okay. [Question]
so i wa just working a completely normal day in fact i felt pretty good i work at a goodwill so it s relatively social but i can handle it cause honestly every person that enters that store is fantastically polite and friendly but for some reason half way through my shift i begin getting light head i assumed it wa my tight hat or my new prescription glass so i took those off and got back to work and for a little bit actually helped but it got worse and worse my hand were shaky and i wa super light headed bless my coworkers cause i mentioned i wasn t feeling great and my manager let me have a break despite not requiring one due to shirt shift one of my coworkers actually spent a dollar to get me a snack and i wa improving i didn t wan na leave these lovely people short staffed a i wa the only product handler closing so i tried getting back on the floor and instantly i wa back in it and again bless my manager cause she suggested it wa fine and i could go home i got in my car and instantly my face felt numb by the time i wa home a relatively short drive my chest wa super numb too im i ve only ever had this feeling once before and i wa wondering if this is what a standard panic attack feel like how do i bring this up with my dad in order to get this figured out sorry if this wa long it actually helped a good bit in getting me relaxed just writing this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've had a challenging day, and I appreciate you sharing your experience with me. It's important to acknowledge that what you're going through is valid and that seeking help is a positive step towards understanding and managing your symptoms.

Based on what you've shared, it seems like you may be experiencing panic attacks. Panic attacks can manifest in various physical symptoms such as lightheadedness, shakiness, and numbness. While it's understandable to question whether it's a panic attack or something else, it's crucial to seek professional guidance to confirm and address these experiences.

In order to bring this up with your dad, it might be helpful to approach the conversation with empathy and openness. You could start by sharing how you've been feeling physically during these episodes and expressing your concern about their recurrence. It may also be beneficial to share any personal experiences or stories from others who have gone through similar situations.

Additionally, providing information about panic attacks and their symptoms can help him better understand what you're experiencing. You could share that panic attacks are intense episodes of anxiety characterized by physical symptoms like rapid heartbeat, shortness of breath, and feelings of dread.

Encouraging your dad to seek professional advice alongside you can also be valuable. By emphasizing the importance of getting a proper diagnosis and treatment plan, you're showing him that this is not a trivial matter and that seeking help is an essential step towards your well-being.

Lastly, it's crucial to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself and your dad as you navigate this process together. Remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, and with time and support, you can find strategies to manage your panic attacks and improve your overall well-being.

I hope these suggestions provide some guidance as you move forward. Remember, I'm here to support you throughout this process.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i had a meeting that i knew wa going to go well but i couldn t control my breathing and my heart rate wa insane i wa filling time with some paperwork but i couldn t focus i tried box breathing and it didn t work forgot to try grounding technique but will moving forward just to mention this pre event anxiety is normal a a kid going to birthday party made me anxious happens all the time still but this is the first time i just couldn t breathe this wa such a worrying experience i have something to actually worry about tomorrow and i hope it doesn t go the same way i honestly don t think it will because my body seems to react to adrenaline differently based on specific situation i am stressed thinking about it now or stressed because i m stressed maybe a soon a i sat down in that meeting i wa completely fine thought it might have been a combination of walking too fast and then my body not recovering from a weird breathing pattern but then i wa walking the same way later completely fine i ve been sighing all day which is what i tend to do when i am stressed i am trying to get help but yeah thing aren t moving along very well i m going to make an appointment with my therapist a soon a possible we are working together on an unrelated issue but i think we ll benefit from talking about it also worried about an upcoming wisdom teeth surgery anyway going to go cry so i can get some of this out of my system

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've had a challenging day, and I'm here to offer some guidance and support. It's normal to experience anxiety before important events, but it's important to find healthy ways to manage it. You mentioned trying box breathing, which can be helpful for some individuals, but it didn't work for you this time. It's worth exploring other relaxation techniques, such as progressive muscle relaxation or guided imagery, to find what works best for you.

Additionally, grounding techniques can be beneficial when feeling overwhelmed. This involves focusing on your senses to bring yourself back to the present moment. For example, you could try noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help shift your attention away from anxious thoughts and into the present.

Your experience of pre-event anxiety is valid, and it's understandable that it can be distressing. However, it's important to recognize that your body's reaction to adrenaline can vary depending on the situation. While it may feel alarming, it's not uncommon for our bodies to respond differently to stressors based on their perceived threat level.

You mentioned feeling stressed about an upcoming wisdom teeth surgery. Surgery can be a source of anxiety for many people, and it's natural to feel worried. It might be helpful to explore coping strategies specific to this event, such as deep breathing exercises, visualization techniques, or even talking to someone who has had a similar experience.

In the meantime, I encourage you to take care of yourself. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help alleviate stress. It's also important to prioritize self-care, such as getting enough sleep, eating well-balanced meals, and engaging in regular physical activity.

I understand that you're trying to get help but feeling like things aren't moving along well. It's important to remember that seeking support is a process, and it can take time to find the right resources and professionals who can assist you. Making an appointment with your therapist is a positive step forward, and I'm glad to hear that you're working together on an unrelated issue. By discussing your concerns in therapy, you'll have the opportunity to explore them further and develop coping strategies tailored to your needs.


[The End of Assistant's Answer]

self explanatory title i can make it through the day when distracted with a busy day at work or surrounded by friend but a soon a i m alone or i have a minute to think i realise how deeply unhappy i am in almost every aspect of my life i don t want to die i know there s thing to live for like family friend travelling new career potential love and child and maybe being one day happy but every day i wake up and struggle i feel little part of my health and sanity being chiseled off one by one and i just don t know how long i can do this for before i just give up

 it's understandable that you're feeling deeply unhappy in various aspects of your life, and it's important to acknowledge the strength it takes to reach out for support. It's great that you've identified some positive things in your life, such as your family, friends, new career, potential love, and the hope of one day being happy. These are all significant sources of fulfillment and joy.

However, it's also crucial to recognize that struggling every day can be incredibly challenging and draining. It's not uncommon to feel like a part of your health and sanity is being chipped away over time. This is where self-care becomes essential. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally can help replenish your energy and improve your overall well-being.

One approach to self-care is creating a routine that includes activities you enjoy and find meaningful. Engaging in hobbies, exercise, mindfulness practices, or connecting with supportive people can provide a sense of purpose and accomplishment. Additionally, setting small achievable goals can help you regain a sense of control and motivation.

It's also important to remember that change takes time and effort. While it may seem overwhelming now, taking small steps towards positive changes can gradually lead to significant improvements. Consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can offer guidance and support during this process.

Lastly, if you ever find yourself in immediate distress or danger, please don't hesitate to contact emergency services or a helpline specifically designed to assist individuals in crisis. They are trained to provide the necessary support and can connect you with additional resources.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are people who genuinely care about your well-being. Take things one step at a time, be kind to yourself, and reach out for support when needed.

[Question]
i have severe anxiety and ocd and i avoided the dating scene until year ago because i honestly wanted to get over my fear and find someone i wa lucky to find a great partner and have been in a good solid relationship for six month yet somehow throughout this whole thing i ve secretly become an absolute wreck i m constantly worrying if this is the right relationship preoccupied with analyzing everything trapped in my thought and making myself utterly miserable ha anyone else experienced this like is this standard for u anxious folk or is this actually a huge red flag that dating or even this person just isn t for me thank you kindly for any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great to hear that you've been able to find a partner and start a solid relationship despite your anxiety and OCD. It takes a lot of courage to face these challenges in the dating scene, and it's commendable that you've been actively working on getting over your fear.

However, it's understandable that being in a relationship can bring up new anxieties and concerns. It's not uncommon for individuals with anxiety to experience preoccupied thoughts and constant worry about the validity of the relationship. This is something many anxious people go through, so you're not alone in feeling this way.

That being said, it's important to remember that everyone's experiences are unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. If your anxiety is significantly impacting your quality of life and happiness in the relationship, it might be helpful to explore some strategies to manage your anxiety.

One approach could be practicing mindfulness techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or meditation, to help ground yourself in the present moment and reduce rumination. Additionally, engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help alleviate stress and provide a sense of balance.

Communication with your partner is also crucial. Sharing your feelings and concerns openly and honestly can foster understanding and support between both of you. Your partner may not fully understand what you're going through, but expressing your needs and boundaries can help create a safe and nurturing environment.

If your anxiety continues to significantly interfere with your daily life and relationship, seeking professional help from a mental health therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders can be beneficial. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific situation.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. Change takes time, and managing anxiety is a journey. Celebrate small victories along the way and give yourself credit for the progress you make.

Ultimately, the decision whether this relationship is right for you is a deeply personal one. Trust your instincts and listen to your inner voice. It's okay to take your time and make sure that you're in a place where you feel comfortable and secure.

I hope these suggestions can help you navigate your anxiety and find some relief. Remember, you're not alone in this, and there are resources available to support you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you've been carrying a heavy burden of depression and disillusionment for a long time, and it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and hopeless about the future. Your experiences of high school and college were challenging, and the trauma you faced during that time has left a deep impact on you. It's important to acknowledge the pain and suffering you've endured and the struggles you've faced in your personal and professional life.

However, it's crucial to remember that while the past can shape our present, it doesn't define our future. You've mentioned feeling miserable and that things have gotten worse for you. It's essential to recognize that this is a common experience for many people, and it's not unique to you. However, it's also important to consider that there are things we can do to improve our situation and find happiness and fulfillment in our lives.

One approach we could explore is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which can help you identify and challenge negative thought patterns that contribute to your feelings of hopelessness and depression. By learning to reframe your thoughts and focus on the positive aspects of your life, you may find that your perspective shifts and you're able to see things in a more optimistic light.

Another approach we could consider is mindfulness-based interventions, such as mindfulness meditation or deep breathing exercises, which can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions and learn to respond to them in a more adaptive and constructive way.

It's also essential to consider your current circumstances and the sources of stress and negativity in your life. We can work together to identify these factors and explore strategies for managing them more effectively. This might include setting realistic goals, prioritizing self-care, and seeking support from friends, family, or a support group.

Ultimately, the therapeutic process is about helping you develop the skills and strategies you need to overcome your mental health challenges and find greater happiness and fulfillment in your life. It's a journey, not a destination, and it's important to remember that progress may not always be linear. [Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of confusion and anxiety about a recent social event with your coworkers. It's understandable that you're feeling this way, especially since you've been apart for so long due to the pandemic. Let's break down the situation and explore some possible explanations for what might be going on.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that your interpretation of the situation could be influenced by your own insecurities and assumptions. While it's possible that there was something you did or said that made your coworker not want to hang out with you today, it's also important to consider alternative explanations. For example, she may have had a different plan in mind or there could be other factors at play that you're not aware of.

Given your close relationship with this coworker, it might be helpful to reach out and have an open and honest conversation about what happened. You can express your feelings and ask for clarification on why she changed her plans last minute. This will give you a clearer understanding of the situation and allow you to address any concerns or misunderstandings that may exist.

In the meantime, try to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that one night of drinking doesn't define your character or your relationships with your coworkers. It's natural to feel anxious when faced with unexpected changes, but it's important to remember that people's plans can change for various reasons unrelated to you.

If your anxiety persists and starts to significantly impact your daily life, it might be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide you with additional guidance and perspective. They can help you explore any underlying insecurities or negative self-beliefs that may be contributing to your anxiety.

Remember, it's normal to feel uncertain in social situations, especially when alcohol is involved. However, it's crucial to approach this situation with open-mindedness and avoid jumping to conclusions or making assumptions about yourself based on others' actions. Take things one step at a time, focus on the present, and remember that you have the ability to build meaningful connections with your coworkers regardless of what happened in the past.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 i can see that you're going through a really tough time right now, and it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and scared. it's important to remember that i'm here to support you and help you navigate these feelings.

it seems like you've been experiencing a lot of physical symptoms, such as tension headaches, dizziness, high blood pressure, and costochondritis pain. these symptoms can be distressing and it's natural to worry about what might be causing them. however, it's crucial to have a medical professional evaluate your condition and provide proper diagnosis and treatment. self-diagnosing or relying on internet research can often lead to unnecessary anxiety and misinterpretation of symptoms.

given your history of anxiety and how certain medications have affected you, it's essential to communicate openly with your doctor about any concerns or side effects you experience. they can then make adjustments or try alternative treatments to find what works best for you. remember, it's okay to ask questions and seek clarification during your appointments to ensure you fully understand your condition and the recommended course of action.

in addition to seeking medical guidance, it may also be helpful for you to explore coping strategies to manage your anxiety and improve your overall well-being. one approach could be practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation. these techniques can help reduce stress and promote a sense of calmness.

engaging in regular physical activity, even if it's just gentle exercises like walking or stretching, can also be beneficial for both your physical and mental health. exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters, and can help alleviate some of the tension and anxiety you're experiencing.

it's also important to prioritize self-care and create a supportive environment for yourself. this might involve setting aside time each day for activities that bring you joy or help you relax, such as reading, listening to music, taking baths, or engaging in hobbies. connecting with loved ones or joining support groups can also provide a sense of community and understanding.

remember, healing is a process that takes time and patience. it's okay to have setbacks along the way, but it's important to keep moving forward and reach out for support when needed. you've shown great strength by reaching out to me today, and i believe in

Your husband's words, "the war trauma will take so long to heal god in heaven i pray for peace to come soon," reflect a deep sense of despair and a longing for a return to normalcy. In this context, it's essential to focus on self-care and finding ways to maintain a sense of routine and normalcy in your daily life.

This might include engaging in activities that bring you joy, such as reading, listening to music, or practicing mindfulness meditation. It's also crucial to prioritize your physical health by ensuring you're eating well, getting regular exercise, and getting enough sleep.

Additionally, it may be helpful to connect with others who are going through similar experiences. This could include joining a support group or reaching out to friends or family members who can offer a listening ear and a source of comfort.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm here to listen and offer support. It's important to acknowledge the pain and difficulty you've been experiencing. Your feelings of depression and the desire to end your life are not something to be taken lightly, and it's crucial that we take this seriously. I want to assure you that there are people who care about you and want to help.

Your history of struggling with depression and suicidal thoughts for a long time is understandably challenging. It's common for individuals dealing with mental health issues to feel misunderstood or unsupported by those around them. However, it's essential to remember that you have the right to seek professional help and support.

The guilt and shame you feel about the actions you took while in a psychotic state are valid emotions. It's natural to feel remorseful and haunted by the consequences of your actions. However, it's important to recognize that seeking help and working towards healing is a sign of strength, not weakness.

You mentioned feeling haunted by demonic forces that try to make you fall and do things you shouldn't. This experience can be incredibly distressing and overwhelming. It's essential to understand that these feelings are not unique to you and can be a manifestation of your mental health struggles.

The thought of committing an unforgivable sin is a heavy burden to carry. It's important to remember that everyone deserves compassion and forgiveness, including yourself. The stigma surrounding mental health and suicide can make it difficult to see past the guilt and shame, but it's crucial to remember that seeking help and support is a sign of strength, not weakness.

I'm glad to hear that you've discarded the thought of committing suicide for now. It's essential to continue reaching out for support and exploring treatment options. Therapy, medication, and support groups can all be helpful tools in managing depression and suicidal thoughts.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take care of yourself. You don't have to face this alone. Reach out to mental health professionals, trusted friends, or family members who can provide support and guidance. [The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling unsure about the labels and diagnoses that have been suggested to you. It's important to remember that these are just potential explanations for what you're experiencing, and they don't define who you are as a person. Instead of focusing on the labels, let's explore some strategies that might help you manage your symptoms and improve your overall well-being.

One strategy that could be helpful is practicing mindfulness. Mindfulness involves paying attention to the present moment without judgment. This can help you break the cycle of overthinking and negative self-talk. You mentioned that you've been replaying scenarios in your head and feeling bad about yourself. Mindfulness can help you observe these thoughts and feelings without getting caught up in them. Instead of dwelling on the past or worrying about the future, you can focus on what's happening right now.

Another strategy that might be helpful is setting small, achievable goals for yourself. This can help you build momentum and give you a sense of accomplishment. Start with something manageable, like taking a short walk outside or completing a small task. As you build confidence and momentum, you can gradually increase the difficulty of your goals. Remember, it's important to be kind to yourself and celebrate even the smallest successes.

Additionally, it might be helpful to create a structured routine for yourself. Having a daily schedule can provide a sense of stability and help you stay focused. Try to establish regular times for waking up, eating meals, working, and engaging in activities that bring you joy. Having a routine can help reduce the amount of decision-making you need to do throughout the day, which can be mentally taxing.

Another strategy that might be helpful is practicing self-care. Self-care involves taking care of your physical, emotional, and mental well-being. This can include things like getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, engaging in regular exercise, and engaging in activities that bring you joy. It's important to prioritize self-care and make it a regular part of your routine.

Lastly, it might be helpful to explore the role of negative self-talk in your experience. You mentioned that your mom kept telling you that others might think negatively about you based on small details. It's important to remember that these thoughts are not facts, and that everyone has insecurities and makes mistakes.

i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time with your anxiety and dissociation. I'm here to support you and offer some guidance on how to manage these experiences.

Firstly, it's important to remember that you're not alone in this. Many people struggle with anxiety and dissociation, and there are strategies that can help alleviate some of the symptoms. One technique that may be helpful is grounding exercises. These exercises involve focusing on your senses to bring yourself back to the present moment. For example, you can try deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or using objects around you to anchor yourself in reality.

Creating a bedtime routine can also be beneficial in promoting better sleep. Establishing a consistent sleep schedule, avoiding stimulating activities before bed, and creating a calming environment in your bedroom can all contribute to a more restful night. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as meditation or gentle stretching before sleep can help reduce anxiety and promote relaxation.

It might be worth exploring coping mechanisms for managing anxiety during the day as well. Engaging in regular exercise, maintaining a balanced diet, and finding enjoyable hobbies or activities can all have a positive impact on your overall well-being and help reduce anxiety levels. Taking breaks throughout the day to engage in self-care activities, such as reading, listening to music, or spending time in nature, can also provide moments of respite and help alleviate stress.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself and give yourself permission to take breaks when needed. It's okay to prioritize self-care and seek support from loved ones or online communities who may be experiencing similar challenges. Sometimes, talking to someone who understands can provide a sense of validation and comfort.

Lastly, if you find that your anxiety and dissociation are significantly impacting your daily life and quality of sleep, it may be beneficial to seek professional help. A mental health professional can provide personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs. They can also explore any underlying factors contributing to your anxiety and dissociation and work with you to develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

I hope these suggestions offer some guidance and support as you navigate through this challenging period. Remember, you have the strength and resilience to overcome this, and there are resources available to assist you along the way.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling with suicidal thoughts. It's important to prioritize your safety and reach out for support. I'd like to help you explore some strategies to cope with your emotions and manage your suicidal ideation.

Firstly, it's crucial to establish a strong support system. Consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can provide a listening ear and offer encouragement. Sometimes, just talking about what you're going through can provide relief and help you gain perspective.

Additionally, therapy can be an invaluable tool in helping you navigate these difficult emotions. A therapist can work with you to identify the underlying causes of your distress and develop coping mechanisms tailored to your specific needs. They can also help you challenge negative self-talk and replace it with more compassionate and realistic thoughts.

In the meantime, there are several self-care practices you can try to boost your mood and overall well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or exercise, can help alleviate stress and improve your mental state. Taking care of your physical health by maintaining a balanced diet, getting regular exercise, and ensuring adequate sleep can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

It's also essential to recognize the importance of setting realistic expectations for yourself. Remember that nobody is perfect, and it's okay to make mistakes or experience setbacks. Instead of focusing on perceived failures, try to celebrate even the smallest victories and give yourself credit for the progress you make.
